general: This law makes sure that buildings used as nursery schools are not charged property taxes, called "non-domestic rates," in England and Wales. This means that these buildings can use their money for things like buying new toys or paying teachers instead of giving it to the government in taxes. The goal is to help these nursery schools provide better care for children.

series.short: The Nursery Grounds Exemption: Agricultural Buildings Exempt from Non-Domestic Rating
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Nursery Grounds Act exempts certain buildings used for agricultural purposes from non-domestic rating.
* Simplified point 2: The exemption applies to buildings that are used solely in connection with agricultural operations at the nursery ground, and not for other commercial activities.
* Simplified point 3: The exemption only applies to England and Wales, and it took effect starting from the 2015/2017 financial years.
* Simplified point 4: The definition of "agricultural building" in the Local Government Finance Act 1988 was amended to include nursery grounds.

summary: The Nursery Grounds Act helps farmers who run childcare businesses on their land by giving them a break on their property taxes. This means they can focus more on taking care of children instead of worrying about paying bills. It also helps keep these important services available in rural areas where there may not be many other job opportunities. This law only applies to England and Wales, and it started helping farmers in 2015/2017. To qualify for the tax break, the buildings must only be used for taking care of plants or animals, and not for other businesses like selling things.
single:
•	Exempts buildings used as nursery grounds from non-domestic rates in England and Wales.
•	Includes buildings that are part of a nursery ground and are used solely in connection with agricultural operations at the nursery ground.
•	Effective for financial years beginning on or after:
	•	April 1, 2015 in England
	•	April 1, 2017 in Wales
•	Applies to England and Wales.
•	Defines “financial year” as a period of 12 months beginning with April 1.
•	May be cited as the Non-Domestic Rating (Nursery Grounds) Act 2018.
In simpler terms, this bill exempts buildings used as nursery grounds from paying non-domestic rates in England and Wales. This includes buildings that are part of a nursery ground and are used solely for agricultural purposes. The bill is effective starting from the 2015 financial year in England and the 2017 financial year in Wales. It only applies to England and Wales.
